article.description:
After yet another off-target heave, former
Cincinnati guard Oscar Robertson turned his head and waved his hand in disgust.
article.headline: Williams' career-best 22 points carry Bearcats
article.linkText: Cincinnati goes cold, but still throttles Florida A&M
article.story:
CINCINNATI (AP) -- After yet another off-target heave, former
Cincinnati guard Oscar Robertson turned his head and waved his hand
in disgust.

	   That's how bad the Bearcats are shooting.

	   Three-point specialist Field Williams regained his touch,
scoring a career-high 22 points, but the rest of his teammates had
another bout of poor shooting as Cincinnati (No. 19 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) beat Florida A&M
80-53 on Tuesday night.

	   The Bearcats (2-0) again found mostly the rim and the backboard
-- and sometimes not even that much -- as they struggled to make
shots for the second straight game.

	   Afterward, coach Bob Huggins scanned the stats sheet and started
shaking his head. His shooters looked as bad on paper as they did
on the court.

	   ''Part of it is we don't pass well, and we're not getting it to
guys where they need to have it,'' Huggins said. ''We shoot ones we
shouldn't, and we don't shoot the ones that we should. Other than
that, we don't have a problem in the world.''

	   Cincinnati went more than nine minutes without a basket Saturday
and shot 27.9 percent from the field -- its worst performance in
nearly 13 years -- during a 54-48 victory over Tennessee Tech.

	   Williams was the only one who could make shots consistently
against Florida A&M (0-2), which stayed close until midway through
the second half. Williams made six of his 11 3-point shots overall.

	   ''I like that we're playing hard,'' said Williams, who was only
2-of-14 in the opener. ''Everybody doesn't know the plays and
everything, but as long as we play hard, we'll be all right.''

	   Leonard Stokes added 14 points for Cincinnati, which shot 42
percent from the field, a figure inflated by a bunch of easy
baskets after the backups took over in the closing minutes.

	   Terrence Woods scored 17 for Florida A&M, which opened its
season with a discouraging three-day visit to Cincinnati. Playing
No. 16 Xavier on the other side of town Sunday, the Rattlers fell
behind by 25 points at halftime and lost 93-64. Point guard Moses
White sprained his ankle in the first minute of that game, and was
limited in his return to the lineup Tuesday.

	   Before the game, Florida A&M fired athletic director Ken Riley,
a former Bengals cornerback, providing the Rattlers with some
intrigue back home.

	   ''There were some indications that it may happen,'' coach Mike
Gillespie said. ''I feel very sorry for him. I wish it could have
been handled differently. We got a new president in July, and you
know how new presidents are -- they want their guy.''

	   Despite the turmoil, the tough trip and the injury-depleted
lineup, the Rattlers stayed with Cincinnati for most of the game,
leaving the crowd of 10,873 either grumbling or numb.

	   After one long 3-point shot by Tony Bobbitt landed well off the
mark, Robertson -- who rarely shows emotion as he sits courtside
with fans -- waved his hand in disgust.

	   Even the usually animated Huggins was at a loss, crouching
motionless by the bench as the Bearcats missed one open shot after
another.

	   Stokes saved Cincinnati in its opener by scoring 15 consecutive
points. This time, Williams stood between the Bearcats and any
chance of an upset.

	   Woods' 3-pointer cut Cincinnati's lead to 21-18 late in the
first half, when the Bearcats were shooting only 32 percent from
the field. Williams, only 2-of-14 from the field in the opener,
then hit rapid-fire 3s to blunt the charge. Another 3-pointer by
Williams made it 35-21 at halftime.

	   ''We lost him a few times and paid for it in the first half,''
Gillespie said. ''That was the difference.''

	   Florida A&M got the lead down to eight in the second half, but
Stokes hit a couple of jumpers, and Cincinnati slowly pulled away.

	   Although Cincinnati repeatedly missed open shots, its extended
man-to-man defense made the difference. The Rattlers shot only 28
percent from the field and had 20 turnovers.
